conclusion: To determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds, we need to analyze the acceleration-time graph provided.
The elevator starts from rest, so the initial velocity v0 = 0.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the acceleration is 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 4 seconds, the acceleration is 2 m/s².
From t = 4 to t = 5 seconds, the acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s².
From t = 5 to t = 55 seconds, the acceleration is 0 m/s².
From t = 55 to t = 56 seconds, the acceleration decreases linearly from 0 m/s² to -2 m/s².
From t = 56 to t = 59 seconds, the acceleration is -2 m/s².
From t = 59 to t = 60 seconds, the acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0 m/s².

premise: Initial velocity v0 = 0, acceleration from t = 0 to t = 1 second is 2 m/s².
conclusion: From t = 0 to t = 1 second, v = 2 m/s.

premise: Velocity at t = 1 second is 2 m/s, acceleration from t = 1 to t = 4 seconds is 2 m/s².
conclusion: From t = 1 to t = 4 seconds, v = 8 m/s.

premise: Velocity at t = 4 seconds is 8 m/s, average acceleration from t = 4 to t = 5 seconds is 1 m/s².
conclusion: From t = 4 to t = 5 seconds, v = 9 m/s.

premise: Velocity at t = 5 seconds is 9 m/s, acceleration from t = 5 to t = 55 seconds is 0 m/s².
conclusion: From t = 5 to t = 55 seconds, v = 9 m/s.

premise: Velocity at t = 55 seconds is 9 m/s, average acceleration from t = 55 to t = 56 seconds is -1 m/s².
conclusion: From t = 55 to t = 56 seconds, v = 8 m/s.

premise: Velocity at t = 56 seconds is 8 m/s, acceleration from t = 56 to t = 59 seconds is -2 m/s².
conclusion: From t = 56 to t = 59 seconds, v = 2 m/s.
